title: Hebrews Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Hebrews chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Hebrews Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Hebrews Chapter 7.

questions.question: Who was Melchisedec described as in Hebrews 7:1?
options: King of Salem and priest of the most high God
King of Israel and prophet
High priest of Aaron
King of Judah and judge
questions.correctAnswer: King of Salem and priest of the most high God
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:1 identifies Melchisedec as king of Salem and priest of the most high God.

questions.question: What did Abraham give to Melchisedec according to Hebrews 7:2?
options: A tenth part of all
A golden crown
A sword
A blessing
questions.correctAnswer: A tenth part of all
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:2 states that Abraham gave Melchisedec a tenth part of all.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 7:3, Melchisedec is described as having no father, mother, or descent. What else is said about him?
options: He has neither beginning of days, nor end of life
He was born in Salem
He was a Levite
He was a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: He has neither beginning of days, nor end of life
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:3 describes Melchisedec as without beginning of days or end of life, made like unto the Son of God.

questions.question: Who receives tithes according to the law, as stated in Hebrews 7:5?
options: The sons of Levi
The kings of Israel
The prophets
The judges
questions.correctAnswer: The sons of Levi
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:5 explains that those of the sons of Levi who receive the priesthood take tithes according to the law.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 7:6, who received tithes from Abraham?
options: Melchisedec, whose descent is not counted from Levi
Aaron
Moses
Levi himself
questions.correctAnswer: Melchisedec, whose descent is not counted from Levi
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:6 states that Melchisedec, not descended from Levi, received tithes from Abraham.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 7:7 states that the lesser is blessed by the better.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:7 clearly says that without all contradiction the less is blessed of the better.

questions.question: What is said about those who die and receive tithes compared to Melchisedec, in Hebrews 7:8?
options: Men that die receive tithes, but Melchisedec receives them from one who lives
Both receive tithes because they live forever
Only men that die receive tithes
Melchisedec did not receive tithes
questions.correctAnswer: Men that die receive tithes, but Melchisedec receives them from one who lives
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:8 contrasts men who die receiving tithes with Melchisedec receiving them from one who lives.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 7:10, where was Levi when Melchisedec met Abraham?
options: In the loins of his father
In Egypt
In Jerusalem
In the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: In the loins of his father
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:10 says Levi was yet in the loins of his father when Melchisedec met Abraham.

questions.question: If perfection could be attained by the Levitical priesthood, what question does Hebrews 7:11 ask?
options: What further need was there for another priest after the order of Melchisedec?
Why did Aaron serve as priest?
Who gave the law to the people?
Why did Levi receive tithes?
questions.correctAnswer: What further need was there for another priest after the order of Melchisedec?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:11 questions the need for another priest if perfection was by the Levitical priesthood.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 7:14 states that our Lord came from the tribe of Judah.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:14 confirms that our Lord sprang out of Judah.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 7:17, Jesus is a priest forever after the order of whom?
options: Melchisedec
Aaron
Levi
Moses
questions.correctAnswer: Melchisedec
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:17 quotes that Jesus is a priest forever after the order of Melchisedec.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 7:19 say the law made nothing perfect, but what brought a better hope?
options: The bringing in of a better hope
The sacrifices of animals
The commandments of Moses
The offerings made by priests
questions.correctAnswer: The bringing in of a better hope
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:19 explains that the law made nothing perfect, but the bringing in of a better hope did.

questions.question: True or False: According to Hebrews 7:23, there were many priests because they died and did not continue.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:23 states there were many priests because they were not allowed to continue by reason of death.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Hebrews 7:25: 'Wherefore he is able also to save them to the uttermost that come unto God by him, seeing he ever _____ to make intercession for them.'
options: liveth
prays
calls
speaks
questions.correctAnswer: liveth
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:25 says Jesus ever liveth to make intercession for them who come to God by him.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 7:27, why does the high priest not need to offer sacrifices daily?
options: Because he offered himself once
Because he is not sinful
Because he is immortal
Because he has many helpers
questions.correctAnswer: Because he offered himself once
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:27 states the high priest does not need to offer daily sacrifices because he offered himself once.

medium.title: Hebrews Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Hebrews Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with discouragement because of the imperfection of human leaders. Based on Hebrews 7, what biblical truth would you share about Jesus’ priesthood?
options: Jesus has an unchangeable priesthood and lives forever to intercede for us
Human priests are perfect and will never fail us
Jesus offered sacrifices daily like other priests
Jesus’ priesthood is temporary and limited to one generation
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus has an unchangeable priesthood and lives forever to intercede for us
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:23-25 teaches that human priests die and do not continue, but Jesus continues forever with an unchangeable priesthood and ever lives to make intercession for us.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 7 instruct us about stewardship and generosity through the example of Abraham?
options: Abraham gave a tenth of all to Melchisedec as an act of faithful giving
Abraham refused to give tithes to anyone outside his tribe
Tithing was only required of the Levites, not of Abraham
Abraham gave everything he had to the priests
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham gave a tenth of all to Melchisedec as an act of faithful giving
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:1-4 describes Abraham giving a tenth of the spoils to Melchisedec, showing faithful and generous stewardship before the law.

questions.question: A believer is confused about why Jesus is called a priest after the order of Melchisedec rather than Aaron. What biblical reason does Hebrews 7 provide?
options: Because Jesus’ priesthood is based on an eternal life and not on the Levitical law
Because Aaron was from the tribe of Judah
Because Melchisedec was a Levite priest
Because Jesus was not a priest at all
questions.correctAnswer: Because Jesus’ priesthood is based on an eternal life and not on the Levitical law
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:11-16 explains that Jesus’ priesthood differs from Aaron’s because it is based on the power of an endless life, not on a carnal commandment of the law.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 7, how does Jesus’ priesthood help us in times of temptation and trials?
options: He lives forever to make intercession for us, providing continual help
He offers sacrifices for our sins daily
He abandons us in trials because He is perfect
He requires us to offer sacrifices for our own sins
questions.correctAnswer: He lives forever to make intercession for us, providing continual help
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:25 emphasizes Jesus’ ongoing intercession for those who come to God through Him, encouraging perseverance through trials.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 7 teach about humility and contentment in the context of priesthood and leadership?
options: Jesus is holy and undefiled, unlike human priests who have weaknesses
Human priests are flawless and need no forgiveness
Everyone should seek to be a priest to gain honor
Priests are unimportant in God’s plan
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus is holy and undefiled, unlike human priests who have weaknesses
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:26-28 contrasts Jesus’ perfect priesthood with the infirmity of human priests, teaching us to rely humbly on Christ’s holiness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Hebrews 7, the law was able to make men perfect priests.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:18-19 clearly states that the law made nothing perfect, but a better hope through Christ brings us near to God.

questions.question: In light of Hebrews 7, what should a Christian’s attitude be about trusting God’s promises during difficult times?
options: Trust in the unchanging priesthood of Jesus who guarantees a better covenant
Trust only in human leaders and their efforts
Doubt God’s promises and rely on self-effort
Ignore prayer and intercession
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the unchanging priesthood of Jesus who guarantees a better covenant
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:21-22 teaches that Jesus was made priest with an oath and is the surety of a better covenant, encouraging trust in God’s unchanging promises.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 7 encourage us to approach prayer and intercession for others?
options: Jesus continually intercedes for us, so we can be confident in prayer for others
Prayer is unnecessary because priests pray for us
Only priests can pray effectively
Intercession is only symbolic and has no real power
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus continually intercedes for us, so we can be confident in prayer for others
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:25 states that Jesus lives to make intercession for those who approach God through Him, encouraging believers to pray confidently.

questions.question: A Christian couple seeks guidance on forgiveness and reconciliation. Based on Hebrews 7, what insight about Jesus’ priesthood can encourage them?
options: Jesus offered Himself once to perfect those who are being sanctified, showing the power of forgiveness
Jesus requires repeated sacrifices for sins
Forgiveness is impossible without priestly mediation
Human priests can fully forgive sins
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus offered Himself once to perfect those who are being sanctified, showing the power of forgiveness
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:27 teaches that Jesus did not need to offer daily sacrifices; He offered Himself once and for all, enabling true forgiveness and reconciliation.

questions.question: True or False: According to Hebrews 7, Melchisedec had a recorded genealogy with known parents.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:3 describes Melchisedec as without father, mother, or descent, emphasizing his priesthood’s eternal nature.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 7 describe the nature of Jesus’ priesthood in relation to eternal life?
options: It is not based on a law of a carnal commandment but on the power of an endless life
It is temporary and limited by human lifespan
It is identical to the Levitical priesthood
It requires continual animal sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: It is not based on a law of a carnal commandment but on the power of an endless life
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:15-16 explains that Jesus’ priesthood arises after the likeness of Melchisedec and is made by the power of an endless life.

questions.question: A believer is questioning the need for Jesus’ priesthood since the law provided priests. How does Hebrews 7 explain this need?
options: Because the Levitical priesthood could not bring perfection, a new priest after Melchisedec’s order was necessary
Because the Levitical priests were perfect
Because Jesus is not a priest
Because the law was more effective than Jesus’ priesthood
questions.correctAnswer: Because the Levitical priesthood could not bring perfection, a new priest after Melchisedec’s order was necessary
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:11-19 discusses the insufficiency of the Levitical priesthood and the necessity of a better hope through Jesus’ eternal priesthood.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 7 help us understand the importance of integrity and honesty in Christian living through the example of Melchisedec?
options: Melchisedec was a king of righteousness and peace, modeling integrity
Melchisedec was dishonest and untrustworthy
Melchisedec required deceptive sacrifices
Melchisedec was irrelevant to Christian living
questions.correctAnswer: Melchisedec was a king of righteousness and peace, modeling integrity
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:2 calls Melchisedec the King of righteousness and King of peace, showing a life of integrity and trustworthiness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hebrews 7 teaches that Jesus is a priest forever after the order of ________.
options: Melchisedec
Aaron
Levi
Judah
questions.correctAnswer: Melchisedec
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:17 and 21 emphasize that Jesus is a priest forever after the order of Melchisedec, differentiating His priesthood from the Levitical order.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 7, what practical attitude should Christians have toward God's changing of the priesthood and law?
options: Accept that a better covenant has come through Jesus and hold to the hope it provides
Reject any change and cling only to the law
Ignore Jesus’ priesthood and focus on human priests
Doubt God’s faithfulness because of changes
questions.correctAnswer: Accept that a better covenant has come through Jesus and hold to the hope it provides
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:12 and 18-19 explain that with the change of priesthood comes a change in law, introducing a better hope through Jesus, which believers should embrace.

hard.title: Hebrews Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Hebrews Chapter 7.

questions.question: Who is Melchisedec described as in Hebrews 7:1?
options: King of Salem and priest of the most high God
King of Israel and prophet
Levite priest and judge
Son of Abraham and priest
questions.correctAnswer: King of Salem and priest of the most high God
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:1 explicitly identifies Melchisedec as the king of Salem and priest of the most high God, meeting Abraham and blessing him.

questions.question: What significant act did Abraham perform for Melchisedec according to Hebrews 7:2?
options: Gave him a tenth part of all
Crowned him king
Offered a burnt sacrifice
Prayed for him
questions.correctAnswer: Gave him a tenth part of all
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:2 states that Abraham gave a tenth part of all to Melchisedec, highlighting Melchisedec’s superiority and Abraham's recognition.

questions.question: What unique characteristics describe Melchisedec's priesthood in Hebrews 7:3?
options: Without father, without mother, without descent, having neither beginning of days nor end of life
Born of Levi and appointed by Moses
Descendant of Aaron with a limited priesthood
Temporary priest during Abraham's time
questions.correctAnswer: Without father, without mother, without descent, having neither beginning of days nor end of life
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:3 describes Melchisedec’s priesthood as eternal and mysterious, unlike the Levitical priesthood tied to genealogy and mortality.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 7:4, why is Melchisedec considered great?
options: Because even Abraham gave him a tenth of the spoils
Because he built the temple in Jerusalem
Because he was the first high priest
Because he led the Israelites out of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Because even Abraham gave him a tenth of the spoils
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:4 emphasizes Melchisedec’s greatness by noting that Abraham, the patriarch, gave him a tithe, showing Melchisedec’s superiority.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 7:5 indicate about the Levitical priests' authority to receive tithes?
options: They receive tithes by commandment according to the law
They can only receive tithes from Gentiles
They receive tithes voluntarily
They do not receive tithes
questions.correctAnswer: They receive tithes by commandment according to the law
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:5 states that Levitical priests are commanded by the law to receive tithes from their brethren.

questions.question: Why is it significant that Melchisedec received tithes from Abraham, according to Hebrews 7:6-7?
options: Because the lesser is blessed by the better
Because Abraham was a priest before Levi
Because tithes were only for Levites
Because Melchisedec was a Levite
questions.correctAnswer: Because the lesser is blessed by the better
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:7 explains that the one who receives the blessing (Melchisedec) is greater than the one who gives it (Abraham), underscoring Melchisedec's superiority.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 7:8 contrast the nature of the priesthood of Melchisedec with the Levitical priesthood?
options: Men who die receive tithes, but Melchisedec receives them from one who lives
Levitical priests are immortal, Melchisedec was mortal
Both priesthoods receive tithes from the same people
Melchisedec’s priesthood ended with his death
questions.correctAnswer: Men who die receive tithes, but Melchisedec receives them from one who lives
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:8 highlights the eternal nature of Melchisedec’s priesthood contrasted with mortal Levitical priests who die.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 7:11 argue about the necessity of a new priesthood after the order of Melchisedec?
options: If perfection were through the Levitical priesthood, there would be no need for another priest
The Levitical priesthood was always perfect
The new priesthood was unnecessary
The priesthood of Aaron was superior
questions.correctAnswer: If perfection were through the Levitical priesthood, there would be no need for another priest
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:11 questions the need for a different priesthood if the Levitical one could bring perfection, suggesting its insufficiency.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 7:13-14, from which tribe does the new priest come and why is this significant?
options: From Judah, a tribe without priestly duties
From Levi, traditionally the priestly tribe
From Benjamin, the warrior tribe
From Ephraim, the largest tribe
questions.correctAnswer: From Judah, a tribe without priestly duties
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:13-14 states the new priest comes from Judah, which differs from the Levitical priesthood, emphasizing a new order of priesthood.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 7:16 mean by saying the new priest is 'made after the power of an endless life'?
options: He has an eternal priesthood not based on the law
He is a mortal priest like others
His priesthood is temporary
He serves only a limited time
questions.correctAnswer: He has an eternal priesthood not based on the law
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:16 contrasts the eternal nature of this priesthood with the temporary Levitical priesthood, emphasizing the unending life and power behind it.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 7:18 describe the effect of changing the priesthood?
options: It necessitates a change in the law
It has no effect on the law
It abolishes all laws
It reinforces the Levitical laws
questions.correctAnswer: It necessitates a change in the law
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:18 states that a change in priesthood requires a corresponding change in the law, indicating a fundamental shift in the covenant.

questions.question: What oath is referenced in Hebrews 7:21 that confirms Jesus' priesthood?
options: "The Lord sware and will not repent, Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec"
"You shall be a prophet like Moses"
"You will be king of Israel"
"You are a priest according to the law of Aaron"
questions.correctAnswer: "The Lord sware and will not repent, Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec"
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:21 quotes the oath that establishes Jesus' eternal priesthood after Melchisedec’s order, distinguishing it from the Levitical priests.

questions.question: What reason does Hebrews 7:23-24 give for Jesus’ priesthood being unchangeable?
options: Because He continues forever and does not die
Because He is from the tribe of Levi
Because He follows the law strictly
Because He was appointed by Moses
questions.correctAnswer: Because He continues forever and does not die
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:23-24 contrasts the many mortal Levitical priests with Jesus’ eternal priesthood, which continues forever without interruption.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 7:25, why is Jesus able to save to the uttermost those who come to God through Him?
options: Because He ever lives to make intercession for them
Because He offered constant sacrifices
Because He was a Levite
Because He was a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Because He ever lives to make intercession for them
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:25 explains that Jesus’ ongoing intercession before God enables Him to save completely those who approach God through Him.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 7:27 states that Jesus needed to offer daily sacrifices for His own sins and the people's sins.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:27 clarifies that unlike other high priests who offer daily sacrifices for themselves and the people, Jesus offered one sacrifice—Himself—once for all.

theological.title: Hebrews Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Hebrews Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who is Melchisedec described as in Hebrews 7:1?
options: King of Salem and priest of the most high God
King of Israel and prophet
High priest of Aaron's order
A Levite priest
questions.correctAnswer: King of Salem and priest of the most high God
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:1 identifies Melchisedec as 'king of Salem, priest of the most high God,' emphasizing his dual role as king and priest. This is consistent with Psalm 110:4 where the Messiah is a priest forever after the order of Melchisedec and Genesis 14:18 where Melchisedec is introduced similarly. This typology points forward to Christ’s eternal priesthood.

questions.question: What did Abraham give to Melchisedec according to Hebrews 7:2?
options: A tenth part of all
Gold and silver
His sword
Land and possessions
questions.correctAnswer: A tenth part of all
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:2 states that Abraham gave Melchisedec 'a tenth part of all,' showing Abraham’s recognition of Melchisedec’s priestly authority. This act also signifies the superiority of Melchisedec’s priesthood over the Levitical priesthood, as Abraham was the ancestor of Levi (Genesis 14:20; Leviticus 27:30).

questions.question: How is Melchisedec’s priesthood described in Hebrews 7:3?
options: Without father, without mother, without descent, having neither beginning of days, nor end of life
A priest appointed by Moses
A descendant of Aaron
A temporary priesthood
questions.correctAnswer: Without father, without mother, without descent, having neither beginning of days, nor end of life
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:3 describes Melchisedec’s priesthood as eternal and mysterious, 'without father, without mother, without descent,' symbolizing the eternal nature of Christ’s priesthood, which is not based on genealogy but on the power of an endless life (Hebrews 7:16). Psalm 110:4 confirms Christ’s eternal priesthood after Melchisedec's order.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 7:5, who has the commandment to take tithes of the people?
options: The sons of Levi who receive the office of the priesthood
The kings of Israel
The prophets
All Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: The sons of Levi who receive the office of the priesthood
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:5 explains that the Levitical priests, descendants of Levi, have the commandment by the law to receive tithes from the people, as outlined in Numbers 18:21 and Deuteronomy 12:6. This contrasts with Melchisedec, who was not of Levi’s line but still received tithes from Abraham.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 7:7 mean by stating, 'the less is blessed of the better'?
options: Melchisedec, the lesser, blessed Abraham, the better
Abraham, the lesser, blessed Melchisedec, the better
The Levitical priests are inferior to Melchisedec
The law is superior to grace
questions.correctAnswer: The Levitical priests are inferior to Melchisedec
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:7 explains that the lesser is blessed by the better, meaning Abraham (the ancestor of Levi) paid tithes to Melchisedec, who is superior. This principle supports the argument that Christ’s priesthood, like Melchisedec’s, is superior to the Levitical priesthood (Psalm 110:4; Genesis 14:18-20).

questions.question: According to Hebrews 7:11, what was the need for another priest after the order of Melchisedec?
options: Because perfection was not attained by the Levitical priesthood
Because Aaron’s priesthood was corrupt
Because the people wanted a new law
Because the temple was destroyed
questions.correctAnswer: Because perfection was not attained by the Levitical priesthood
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:11 states that if perfection had been attained through the Levitical priesthood, there would be no need for another priest after Melchisedec’s order. This shows the insufficiency of the old covenant priesthood and the necessity of Christ’s superior, eternal priesthood (Hebrews 7:18-19; Psalm 110:4).

questions.question: From which tribe did Christ arise according to Hebrews 7:14?
options: Judah
Levi
Benjamin
Ephraim
questions.correctAnswer: Judah
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:14 clearly states that Jesus came from the tribe of Judah, a tribe not associated with the Levitical priesthood (Numbers 1:5-15; Genesis 49:10). This supports the argument that Christ’s priesthood is of a different order, not based on the Aaronic lineage but on Melchisedec’s eternal priesthood.

questions.question: Hebrews 7:16 describes Christ’s priesthood as made not after the law of a carnal commandment, but after what?
options: The power of an endless life
The law of Moses
The customs of the Levites
The traditions of men
questions.correctAnswer: The power of an endless life
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:16 teaches that Christ’s priesthood is established by the power of an endless life, emphasizing His eternal nature and divine appointment, unlike the temporary Levitical priests who died. This eternal life is central to Christ’s ability to intercede permanently (John 11:25; Revelation 1:18).

questions.question: What oath is mentioned in Hebrews 7:21 that confirms Jesus as a priest forever?
options: The Lord swore and will not repent, 'Thou art a priest forever after the order of Melchisedec'
The covenant with Abraham
The promise to David
The law of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord swore and will not repent, 'Thou art a priest forever after the order of Melchisedec'
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:21 quotes Psalm 110:4 to show God’s oath confirming Jesus’ eternal priesthood after Melchisedec’s order, unlike Levitical priests who were appointed without an oath. This divine oath underscores the unchangeable and superior nature of Christ’s priesthood.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 7:24, what is distinctive about Christ’s priesthood?
options: It is unchangeable because He continues forever
It is temporary like the Levitical priesthood
It requires daily sacrifices
It is based on genealogy
questions.correctAnswer: It is unchangeable because He continues forever
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:24 states that Christ’s priesthood is unchangeable because He lives forever, contrasting with the many Levitical priests who died and could not continue. This eternal priesthood assures believers of a permanent intercession (Hebrews 7:23; Psalm 110:4).

questions.question: Why does Christ not need to offer sacrifices daily according to Hebrews 7:27?
options: Because He offered Himself once for all
Because He is sinless
Because He is not a priest
Because sacrifices are no longer needed
questions.correctAnswer: Because He offered Himself once for all
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:27 explains that unlike Levitical priests who offer sacrifices daily for their own sins and the people’s, Christ offered Himself once for all, making the sacrifice perfect and complete (Hebrews 9:12; 10:10). This sufficiency is foundational to Christian soteriology.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 7:19 say about the law and perfection?
options: The law made nothing perfect, but bringing in a better hope did
The law was sufficient for salvation
The law was abolished completely
The law was given to the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: The law made nothing perfect, but bringing in a better hope did
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:19 acknowledges the insufficiency of the Mosaic law to bring perfection, emphasizing that a better hope through Christ allows believers to draw near to God. This is consistent with Romans 8:3-4 and Galatians 3:24, which show Christ fulfilling the law’s purpose.

questions.question: What is the significance of Christ being a surety of a better testament according to Hebrews 7:22?
options: He guarantees the new covenant that provides eternal salvation
He replaces the old covenant with a political kingdom
He confirms the Levitical priesthood
He establishes a temporary covenant
questions.correctAnswer: He guarantees the new covenant that provides eternal salvation
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:22 declares Jesus as the surety of a better covenant, meaning He guarantees the promises of God in the new covenant, superior to the old covenant given through Moses (Jeremiah 31:31-34; Hebrews 8:6). This covenant ensures eternal redemption (Hebrews 9:15).

questions.question: Hebrews 7:25 emphasizes Christ’s ability to save to the uttermost those who come to God by Him because:
options: He ever liveth to make intercession for them
He is a mortal high priest
He offers daily sacrifices
He is a Levite
questions.correctAnswer: He ever liveth to make intercession for them
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:25 teaches that Christ’s eternal life enables Him to intercede continually for believers, ensuring complete salvation. This ongoing intercession is unique to Christ’s eternal priesthood (Romans 8:34; 1 John 2:1).

questions.question: What does Hebrews 7:26 say about the character of the high priest who is suitable for believers?
options: Holy, harmless, undefiled, separate from sinners, exalted above the heavens
Sinful but merciful
A mortal man with weaknesses
A political leader
questions.correctAnswer: Holy, harmless, undefiled, separate from sinners, exalted above the heavens
questions.explanation: Hebrews 7:26 describes Christ as the perfect high priest—holy and without sin, distinct from sinners, and exalted above all creation. This contrasts with human priests who have infirmities (Hebrews 4:15; 1 Peter 1:19).
